children.subject:
Yes, beyond the limitations of the new scheduling system, difficulties were compounded by none of us having the information about what those would be with any advance notice.  The current set-up (including discussions not appearing on your individual schedules) was an attempt to preserve achieving the educational mission-driven goal of having students in labs and discussions with the same TA and same set of students, to build the possibility of learning community inside these large classes. 

Starting in spring, we will most likely have students sign up separately for labs and discussions that in most cases will not be connected at all.  We will probably abandon supporting learning communities (in this particular way) to accommodate the system limitations we've been given.  Honestly, it makes me sad.  I haven't taken CS160 but I imagine creating human-computer interfaces that make humans give up on philosophical ideals to accommodate system design is probably not best practice.

I see it, thank you so much!


Honestly, not including discussion in schedule makes the job really tedious because I've to look at discussion times, my schedule of other classes, lab waitlist, and possible clashes at the same time.

history.content:
It says, "Students who sign up for lab 102C are expected to attend discussion section 102B."

But where do I check times for discussion section 102B or so on?
history.subject: CS 61C discussion time
